title: 110_s2883
content: The Act is titled the "Mother's Day Centennial Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that Anna Jarvis, founder of modern Mother's Day, was born in Webster, West Virginia in 1864. She dedicated her life to honoring her mother, Anna Reeves Jarvis, leading to the official proclamation of Mother's Day in 1908. Governor William Glasscock issued the first Mother's Day Proclamation in 1910, and in 1914, the Sixty-Third Congress designated the second Sunday in May as Mother's Day. The Sixty-Third Congress designated the second Sunday in May as Mother's Day and encouraged displaying the American flag as a public expression of love for mothers. President Woodrow Wilson issued a proclamation in 1914 for government officials and the American people to display the flag on Mother's Day. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 coins with specific specifications, including weight, diameter, and metal composition. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted under this Act commemorates the 100th anniversary of Mother's Day. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year 2014, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2014, with sales possible before that date. Minting authority will end on December 31, 2014. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales must include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges will be divided equally between the Susan G. Komen for the Cure and the National Osteoporosis Foundation for research purposes. Both organizations will be audited for the funds received.
